siblingDuality.connection: Joseph's two sons, blessed by their grandfather Jacob with crossed hands. The younger Ephraim received the greater blessing, continuing the biblical pattern of younger-over-elder. Their blessing became the blessing Jewish parents give their sons every Friday night.

rivalryResearch.relationship: Ephraim and Manasseh were Joseph's two sons, born in Egypt. When Jacob blessed them before his death, he deliberately crossed his hands to put his right hand on Ephraim (the younger) and left on Manasseh (the firstborn). When Joseph tried to correct him, Jacob insisted: 'I know, my son, I know. He also shall become a people, and he also shall be great; but truly his younger brother shall be greater.' Their blessing became the standard blessing for Jewish sons.

keyMoments.title: Born in Egypt
keyMoments.description: Joseph named his firstborn Manasseh ('making to forget') because 'God has made me forget all my hardship.' He named the second Ephraim ('fruitfulness') because 'God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.'

keyMoments.title: Brought Before Jacob
keyMoments.description: Joseph brought his two sons to his dying father Jacob for blessing. He positioned Manasseh at Jacob's right hand (for the greater blessing) and Ephraim at the left.

keyMoments.title: The Crossed Hands
keyMoments.description: Jacob stretched out his right hand and laid it on Ephraim's head, though he was the younger, and his left hand on Manasseh's head, crossing his hands intentionally.

keyMoments.title: Joseph's Protest
keyMoments.description: When Joseph saw it, he was displeased and tried to move his father's right hand from Ephraim's head to Manasseh's: 'Not so, my father, for this one is the firstborn; put your right hand on his head.'

keyMoments.title: Jacob's Insistence
keyMoments.description: Jacob refused: 'I know, my son, I know. He also shall become a people, and he also shall be great; but truly his younger brother shall be greater than he, and his offspring shall become a multitude of nations.'

keyMoments.title: The Blessing
keyMoments.description: Jacob blessed them: 'By you Israel will pronounce blessings, saying: God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.' This became the blessing Jewish parents give their sons every Shabbat.

rivalryScenes.heroAction: Young Ephraim receiving Jacob's right hand on his head, looking up at his grandfather with innocent acceptance. He doesn't understand the significance, but receives the greater blessing.
rivalryScenes.villainAction: Young Manasseh receiving Jacob's left hand on his head, perhaps looking confused at the crossing. The firstborn receiving the lesser blessing, but blessed nonetheless.
rivalryScenes.scene: Jacob's deathbed in Egypt. The old patriarch with hands deliberately crossed, the two boys before him, Joseph looking on in concern.

rivalryScenes.heroAction: Ephraim standing quietly, the blessing already given. The younger who was chosen, the pattern repeated (Isaac over Ishmael, Jacob over Esau, Joseph over his brothers).
rivalryScenes.villainAction: Manasseh watching as his father Joseph reaches to correct Jacob's hands. 'Not so, my father, this one is the firstborn.' The moment of displacement.
rivalryScenes.scene: The same blessing scene, focus on Joseph's hands reaching to move Jacob's. Jacob's face firm with prophetic knowledge.

rivalryScenes.heroAction: Ephraim and Manasseh side by side, both blessed. Ephraim slightly forward or highlighted, but both clearly loved. 'He also shall be great.'
rivalryScenes.villainAction: Manasseh beside Ephraim, also blessed. Not rejected but different. 'He also shall become a people, and he also shall be great.' Second but not forgotten.
rivalryScenes.scene: The two brothers together after the blessing. Both touched by Jacob's hands, both part of Israel. Unity despite the distinction.
